revision.comment: /* The ICMEg project and its mission */-, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: identifcation → identification
revision.text:
{{Technical|date=February 2016}} '''Integrated Computational Materials Engineering''' (ICME) is an approach to design products, the materials that comprise them, and their associated materials processing methods by linking materials models at multiple length scales. Key words are "Integrated", involving integrating models at multiple length scales, and "[[Engineering]]", signifying industrial utility. The focus is on the materials, i.e. understanding how processes produce material [[microstructure|structures]], how those structures give rise to [[list of materials properties|material properties]], and how to [[material selection|select materials]] for a given application. The key links are process-structures-properties-performance.<ref name=Olson>{{cite journal|last=Olson|first=Gregory B.|journal=Science|date=May 2000|volume=288|pages=993–998|url=http://srg.northwestern.edu/Publications%20Library/Journals/2000_DesigningNewMaterialWorld_Science_small.pdf|doi=10.1126/science.288.5468.993 |title= Designing a New Material World }}</ref> The National Academies report<ref name=NationalAcademiesReport>{{cite book|last=Committee on Integrated Computational Materials Engineering, National Materials Advisory Board, Division on Engineering and Physical Sciences, National Research Council|title=Integrated Computational Materials Engineering: A Transformational Discipline for Improved Competitiveness and National Security|year=2008|publisher=National Academies Press|pages=132|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JlfSnH8jI4UC&dq=Standardized+information+exchange+in+Integrated+Computational+Materials+Engineering+-wikipedia|isbn=9780309178211}}</ref> describes the need for using multiscale materials modeling<ref name=Horstemeyer>{{cite book|title=Practical Aspects of Computational Chemistry|year=2009|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-90-481-2686-6|author=M.F. Horstemeyer|authorlink=Multiscale Modeling: A Review|editor1=J. Leszczynski |editor2=M. K. Shukla }}</ref> to capture the process-structures-properties-performance of a material.
== Standardization in ICME == A fundamental requirement to meet the ambitious ICME objective of designing materials for specific products resp. components is an integrative and interdisciplinary computational description of the history of the component starting from the sound initial condition of a homogeneous, isotropic and stress free melt resp. gas phase and continuing via subsequent processing steps and eventually ending in the description of failure onset under operational load.<ref name=NationalAcademiesReport /><ref name=Panchal>{{cite journal|last=Panchal|first=Jitesh H.|author2=Surya R. Kalidindi |author3=David L. McDowell |title=Key computational modeling issues in Integrated Computational Materials Engineering|journal=Computer-Aided Design|year=2013|volume=45|issue=1|pages= 4–25|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010448512001352|doi=10.1016/j.cad.2012.06.006}}</ref>
Integrated Computational Materials Engineering is an approach to design products, the materials that comprise them, and their associated materials processing methods by linking materials models at multiple length scales. ICME thus naturally requires the combination of a variety of models and software tools. It is thus a common objective to build up a scientific network of stakeholders concentrating on boosting ICME into industrial application by defining a common communication standard for ICME relevant tools.<ref name=Schmitz>{{cite book|title=Integrative Computational Materials Engineering- Concepts and applications of a modular simulation platform|year=2012|publisher=Wiley VCH Verlag|location=Weinheim|isbn=978-3-527-33081-2|editor=Schmitz, G. J. |editor2=Prahl,U.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society (TMS)|title=Proceedings of the 1st World Congress on Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME)|year=2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=111814774X|pages=275|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_lsX4IEHofQC&dq=Standardized+information+exchange+in+Integrated+Computational+Materials+Engineering+-wikipedia}}</ref>
== Standardization of information exchange ==
[[File:ICMEg concept.jpg|right|thumb|284x284px]] Efforts to generate a common language by standardizing and generalizing data formats for the exchange of simulation results represent a major mandatory step towards successful future applications of ICME. A future, structural framework for ICME comprising a variety of academic and/or commercial simulation tools operating on different scales and being modular interconnected by a common language in form of standardized data exchange will allow integrating different disciplines along the production chain, which by now have only scarcely interacted. This will substantially improve the understanding of individual processes by integrating the component history originating from preceding steps as the initial condition for the actual process. Eventually this will lead to optimized process and production scenarios and will allow effective tailoring of specific materials and component properties.<ref name=Schmitz_2009>{{cite journal|last=Schmitz|first=G.J.|author2=Prahl, U.|title=Toward a virtual platform for materials processing|journal=JOM|year=2009|volume=61|issue=5|doi=10.1007/s11837-009-0064-0|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11837-009-0064-0|pages=19–23}}</ref>
=== The ICMEg project and its mission ===
The ICMEg<ref name=icmeg.eu>{{cite web|title=ICMEg project|url=http://icmeg.eu}}</ref> project aims to build up a scientific network of stakeholders concentrating on boosting ICME into industrial application by defining a common communication standard for ICME relevant tools. Eventually this will allow stakeholders from electronic, atomistic, mesoscopic and continuum communities to benefit from sharing knowledge and best practice and thus to promote a deeper understanding between the different communities of materials scientists, IT engineers and industrial users.
ICMEg will create an international network of simulation providers and users.<ref name=icmeg.workshop>{{cite web|title=ICMEg workshops|url=http://www.icmeg.euproject.info/icmeg-workshop.html}}</ref> It will promote a deeper understanding between the different communities (academia and industry) each of them by now using very different tools/methods and data formats. The harmonization and standardization of information exchange along the life-cycle of a component and across the different scales (electronic, atomistic, mesoscopic, continuum) are the key activity of ICMEg.
The mission of ICMEg is * to establish and to maintain a network of contacts to simulation software providers, governmental and international standardization authorities, ICME users, associations in the area of materials and processing, and academia * to define and communicate an ICME language in form of an open and standardized communication protocol * to stimulate knowledge sharing in the field of multiscale materials design * to identify missing tools, models and functionalities and propose a roadmap for their development * to discuss and to decide about future amendments to the initial standard
The activities of ICMEg include * Organization of International Workshops on Software Solutions for Integrated Computational Materials Engineering<ref name=icmeg.workshop /> * Conducting market study and surwey on available simulation software for ICME<ref name=icmeg.eu /> * Create and maintain forum for knowledge sharing in ICME <ref name=icmeg.eu />
The ICMEg project ended in October 2016. Its major outcomes are
* a Handbook of Software Solutions for ICME <ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=Schmitz|first=Georg J.|title=Introduction|date=2016-09-23|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/9783527693566.ch1|work=Handbook of Software Solutions for ICME|pages=1–17|publisher=Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA|language=en|doi=10.1002/9783527693566.ch1|isbn=9783527693566|access-date=2018-07-11|last2=Prahl|first2=Ulrich}}</ref> * the identification of [[Hdf5|HDF5]] as a suitable communication file standard for microstructure information exchange in ICME settings <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schmitz|first=Georg J.|date=2016|title=Microstructure modeling in integrated computational materials engineering (ICME) settings: Can HDF5 provide the basis for an emerging standard for describing microstructures?|url=|journal=JOMM|volume=68 1|pages=77–83|via=}}</ref> * the specification of a metadata description for microstructures<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schmitz|first=Georg J.|last2=Böttger|first2=Bernd|last3=Apel|first3=Markus|last4=Eiken|first4=Janin|last5=Laschet|first5=Gottfried|last6=Altenfeld|first6=Ralph|last7=Berger|first7=Ralf|last8=Boussinot|first8=Guillaume|last9=Viardin|first9=Alexandre|date=2016|title=Towards a metadata scheme for the description of materials – the description of microstructures|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14686996.2016.1194166|journal=Science and Technology of Advanced Materials|language=en|volume=17|issue=1|pages=410–430|doi=10.1080/14686996.2016.1194166|issn=1468-6996|pmc=5111567|pmid=27877892|via=}}</ref> * a network of stakeholders in the area of ICME
Most of the activities being launched in the ICMEg project are continued by the [http://www.emmc.info European Materials Modelling Council] and in the [http://the-marketplace-project.eu MarketPlace project]
== Multiscale modeling in material processing == [[Multiscale modeling]] aims to evaluate material properties or behavior on one level using information or models from different levels and properties of elementary processes. Usually, the following levels, addressing a phenomenon over a specific window of length and time, are recognized:
* Structural scale: [[Finite element method|Finite element]], [[finite volume method|finite volume]] and [[finite difference method|finite difference]] [[partial differential equation]] are solvers used to simulate structural responses such as [[solid mechanics]] and [[transport phenomena]] at large (meters) scales. ** process modeling/simulations: extrusion, rolling, sheet forming, stamping, casting, welding, etc. ** product modeling/simulations: performance, impact, fatigue, corrosion, etc. * Macroscale: constitutive (rheology) equations are used at the continuum level in [[solid mechanics]] and [[transport phenomena]] at millimeter scales. * Mesoscale: continuum level formulations are used with discrete quantities at multiple micrometre scale. "Meso" is an ambiguous term that means "intermediate" so it has been used as representing different intermediate scales. In this context it can represent modeling from crystal plasticity for metals, Eshelby solutions for any materials, homogenization methods, and unit cell methods. * Microscale: modeling techniques that represent the micrometre scale such as dislocation dynamics codes for metals and phase field models for multiphase materials. [[Phase field models]] of [[phase transition]]s and [[microstructure]] formation and evolution on nanometer to millimeter scales. * Nanoscale: semi-empirical atomistic methods are used such as Lennard-Jones, Brenner potentials, embedded atom method (EAM) potentials, and modified embedded atom potentials (MEAM) in [[molecular dynamics]] (MD), molecular statics (MS), [[Monte Carlo method|Monte Carlo]] (MC), and [[kinetic Monte Carlo]] (KMC) formulations. * Electronic scale: Schroedinger equations are used in computational framework as [[density functional theory]] (DFT) models of electron orbitals and bonding on angstrom to nanometer scales.
There are some software codes that operate on different length scales such as:
*[[CALPHAD]] computational [[thermodynamics]] for prediction of equilibrium [[phase diagram]]s and even non-equilibrium phases. *[[Phase field models#Software|''Phase field codes'']] for simulation of microstructure evolution *[[Database]]s of processing parameters, [[microstructure]] features, and [[list of materials properties|properties]] from which one can draw correlations at various length scales *[https://www.geodict.com GeoDict] - The Digital Material Laboratory by [https://www.math2market.de Math2Market] *[http://vextec.com/demos/ VPS-MICRO] is a multiscale probabilistic fracture mechanics software. *[http://analyswift.com/swiftcomp-vamuch-micromechanics-modeling-of-heterogeneous-materials/ SwiftComp] is a multiscale constitutive modeling software based on mechanics of structure genome.
A comprehensive compilation of software tools with relevance for ICME is documented in the Handbook of Software Solutions for ICME<ref name=":0" />
== Examples of Model integration ==
*Small scale models calculate [[list of materials properties|material properties]], or relationships between properties and parameters, e.g. [[yield (engineering)|yield strength]] vs. [[temperature]], for use in continuum models *[[CALPHAD]] computational thermodynamics software predicts free energy as a function of composition; a phase field model then uses this to predict structure formation and development, which one may then correlate with properties. *An essential ingredient to model microstructure evolution by [[phase field models]] and other microstructre evolution codes are the initial and boundary conditions. While boundary conditions may be taken e.g. from the simulation of the actual process, the initial conditions (i.e. the initial microstructure entering into the actual process step) involve the entire integrated process history starting from the homogeneous, isotropic and stress free melt. Thus - for a successful ICME - an efficient exchange of information along the entire process chain and across all relevant length scales is mandatory. The models to be combined for this purpose comprise both academic and/or commercial modelling tools and simulation software packages. To streamline the information flow within this heterogeneous variety of modelling tools, the concept of a modular, standardized simulation platform has recently been proposed.<ref name=Schmitz /> A first realisation of this concept is the [http://www.aixvipmap.de '' AixViPMaP® '']- the Aachen Virtual Platform for Materials Processing. *Process models calculate spatial distribution of structure features, e.g. fiber density and orientation in a [[composite material]]; small-scale models then calculate relationships between structure and properties, for use in a continuum models of overall part or system behavior *Large scale models explicitly fully couple with small scale models, e.g. a [[fracture]] simulation might integrate a continuum solid mechanics model of macroscopic deformation with an FD model of atomic motions at the crack tip *Suites of models (large-scale, small-scale, atomic-scale, process-structure, structure-properties, etc.) can be hierarchically integrated into a systems design framework to enable the computational design of entirely new materials. A commercial leader in the use of ICME in computational materials design is [http://www.questek.com QuesTek Innovations LLC], a small business in Evanston, IL co-founded by [http://www.matsci.northwestern.edu/faculty/gbo.html Prof. Greg Olson of Northwestern University]. QuesTek's high-performance [http://www.questek.com/iron-based-alloys.html ''Ferrium®''] steels were designed and developed using ICME methodologies. *The [[Mississippi State University]] Internal State Variable (ISV) plasticity-damage model (DMG)<ref>{{cite web|title=Material Models|url=https://icme.hpc.msstate.edu/mediawiki/index.php/Material_Models}}</ref> developed by a [http://www.cavs.msstate.edu team] led by Prof. Mark F. Horstemeyer (Founder of [http://www.predictivedesigntech.com Predictive Design Technologies]) has been used to optimize the design of a Cadillac control arm,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Horstemeyer|first=M.F.|author2=Wang, P.|title=Cradle-to-Grave simulation-Based Design Incorporating Multiscale Microstructure-Property Modeling: Reinvigorating Design with Science|journal=J. Computer-Aided Materials Design|year=2003|volume=10|pages=13–34|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023%2FB%3AJCAD.0000024171.13480.24|accessdate=19 March 2014|doi=10.1023/b:jcad.0000024171.13480.24}}</ref> the Corvette engine cradle,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Horstemeyer|first=M.F. |author2=D. Oglesby |author3=J. Fan |author4=P.M. Gullett |author5=H. El Kadiri |author6=Y. Xue |author7=C. Burton |author8=K. Gall |author9=B. Jelinek |author10=M.K. Jones |author11=S. G. Kim |author12=E.B. Marin |author13=D.L. McDowell |author14=A. Oppedal |author15=N. Yang |title=From Atoms to Autos: Designing a Mg Alloy Corvette Cradle by Employing Hierarchical Multiscale Microstructure-Property Models for Monotonic and Cyclic Loads|journal=MSU.CAVS.CMD.2007-R0001|year=2007}}</ref> and a powder metal steel engine bearing cap.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Horstemeyer|first=M.F.|author2=Hammi, Y |author3=Sanderow, H. |author4=Chernenkoff, R. |author5=Weber, G. |title=Powder-Metal Performance Modeling of Automotive Components|journal=AMD-410|year=2009}}</ref> *[[ESI Group]] through its [http://www.esi-group.com/software-services/virtual-manufacturing/casting ProCast] and [http://www.esi-group.com/software-services/virtual-manufacturing/welding-assembly SYSWeld] are commercial finite element solutions used in production environments by major manufacturers in aerospace, automotive and government organizations to simulate local material phase changes of metals prior to manufacturing. [http://www.esi-group.com/software-services/virtual-manufacturing/composites PAMFORM] is utilized for tracking material changes during composite forming manufacturing simulation.
==Education==
Katsuyo Thorton announced at the 2010 MS&T ICME Technical Committee meeting that NSF would be funding a "[http://www.umich.edu/~mctp/SciPrgPgs/events/2012/SS12/sponsors.html Summer School]" on ICME at the [[University of Michigan]] starting in 2011. Northwestern began offering a [http://www.mccormick.northwestern.edu/materials-science/documents/graduate/icme-brochure.pdf Masters of Science Certificate] in ICME in the fall of 2011. The first Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME) course based upon Horstemeyer 2012<ref name="Horstemeyer 2012" /> was delivered at Mississippi State University (MSU) in 2012 as a graduate course with distance learning students included [c.f., Sukhija et al., 2013]. It was later was taught in 2013 and 2014 at MSU also with distance learning students. In 2015, the [https://icme.hpc.msstate.edu/mediawiki/index.php/Mississippi_State_University ICME Course] was taught by Dr. Mark Horstemeyer (MSU) and Dr. William (Bill) Shelton (Louisiana State University, LSU) with students from each institution via distance learning. The goal of the methodology embraced in this course was to provide students with the basic skills to take advantage of the computational tools and experimental data provided by EVOCD in conducting simulations and bridging procedures for quantifying the structure-property relationships of materials at multiple length scales. On successful completion of the assigned projects, students published their multiscale modeling learning outcomes on the [http://icme.hpc.msstate.edu/ ICME Wiki], facilitating easy assessment of student achievements and embracing qualities set by the ABET engineering accreditation board.
== See also == *[[Materials informatics]] *[[ICME cyberinfrastructure]] *[[Cyberinfrastructure]]
== References == <ref name="Horstemeyer 2012"> {{cite book |first1=M. F. |last1=Horstemeyer |year=2012 |title=Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME) for Metals |isbn=978-1-118-02252-8}} </ref> {{reflist}}
*[[JOM]] [http://doc.tms.org/servlet/ProductCatalog?container=JOM+2006+November November 2006 issue] focused on ICME *Committee on Integrated Computational Materials Engineering, National Research Council, ''Integrated Computational Materials Engineering: A Transformational Discipline for Improved Competitiveness and National Security,'' National Academies Press, 2008. {{ISBN|0-309-11999-5}}, [http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=12199 NAP Link] * [http://srg.northwestern.edu/Publications%20Library/Journals/2000_DesigningNewMaterialWorld_Science_small.pdf G. Olson, Designing a New Material Word, Science, Vol. 288, May 12, 2000] * Horstemeyer 2009: [https://books.google.com/books?id=esOANcsz5w8C&lpg=PA87&ots=K6oNsRlsI5&dq=multiscale%20modeling%20a%20review%20Horstemeyer&pg=PR3#v=onepage&q=multiscale%20modeling%20a%20review%20Horstemeyer&f=false Horstemeyer M.F., "Multiscale Modeling: A Review," ''Practical Aspects of Computational Chemistry'', ed. J. Leszczynski and M.K. Shukla, Springer Science+Business Media, pp. 87-135, 2009]
== External links == *[http://materialstechnology.tms.org/icme/icmeHome.asp ICME section] of [http://materialstechnology.tms.org/ Materials Technology @ TMS] *[Advances in ICME Implementation: Concepts and Practices” in the May 2017 issue (vol. 69, no. 5) of [[JOM]] https://link.springer.com/journal/11837/69/5] *[http://icme.hpc.msstate.edu/ Cyberinfrastructure for ICME at Mississippi State University] *[http://www.geodict.com GeoDict virtual material laboratory]
<!--Categories--> [[Category:Materials science]] [[Category:Engineering]]

page.title: International Committee for Information Technology Standards

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = InterNational Committee for Information Technology Standards |image = |image_border = | logo = INCITS logo.svg |size = <!-- default 200px --> |alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> |caption = |map = <!-- optional --> |msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt = <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption = <!-- optional --> |abbreviation = INCITS |motto = |established = {{Start date and age|1961|paren=yes}} |type = |status = |purpose = [[Standards organization]] |headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States|U.S.]] |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = <!--(position title for the leader of the org)--> |leader_name = <!--(name of leader)--> |main_organ = <!--(gral. assembly, board of directors, etc)--> |parent_organization = <!--(if one)--> |affiliations = <!--(if any)--> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL|http://www.incits.org/}} |remarks = }}
The '''InterNational Committee for Information Technology Standards''' ('''INCITS'''), (pronounced "insights"),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.incits.org|title=About INCITS}}</ref> is an [[ANSI]]-accredited standards development organization composed of [[Information technology]] developers. It was formerly known as the '''X3''' and '''NCITS'''.
INCITS is the central U.S. forum dedicated to creating technology standards. INCITS is accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) and is affiliated with the Information Technology Industry Council, a global policy advocacy organization that represents U.S. and global innovation companies.
INCITS coordinates technical standards activity between ANSI in the USA and joint [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]]/[[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] committees worldwide. This provides a mechanism to create standards that will be implemented in many nations. As such, INCITS' executive board also serves as ANSI's Technical Advisory Group for ISO/IEC Joint Technical Committee 1. JTC 1 is responsible for International standardization in the field of information technology. INCITS operates through consensus. Many times, the U.S. standard that INCITS members develop then will become the baseline standard for the international community.
==Governance== INCITS is guided by its executive board. The INCITS executive board established more than 50 Technical Committees, Task Groups and Study Groups that are constantly developing standards for new technologies and updating standards for older products.
==Standards development== More than 750 standards have been created and approved through the INCITS process, with another 800 in development. American National Standards are voluntary and serve U.S. interests well because all materially affected stakeholders have the opportunity to work together to create them. INCITS-approved standards only become mandatory when, and if, they are adopted or referenced by the government or when market forces make them imperative.
Given the responsibilities and the expenditures associated with U.S. participation in international standards activities, INCITS considers participation as a "P" member of ISO/IEC JTC 1, as a declaration of support for the international committee’s technical work. INCITS policy is to adopt as "Identical" American National Standards all ISO/IEC or ISO standards that fall within its program of work, with exceptions as outlined in our procedures. Accordingly, INCITS will adopt as "Identical" American National Standards all ISO/IEC or ISO standards that fall within its program of work. Similarly, INCITS will withdraw any such adopted American National Standard that has been withdrawn as an ISO/IEC or ISO International Standards.
==History== INCITS was established in 1961 as the Accredited Standards Committee X3, Information Technology'and is sponsored by [[Information Technology Industry Council]] (ITI), a trade association representing providers of information technology products and services then known as the Business Equipment Manufacturers Association (BEMA) and later renamed the Computer and Business Equipment Manufacturers' Association (CBEMA). The first organizational meeting was in February 1961 with ITI (CBEMA then) taking Secretariat responsibility. X3 was established under [[American National Standards Institute]] (ANSI) procedures. The forum was renamed Accredited Standards Committee NCITS, National Committee for Information Technology Standards in 1997, and the current name was approved in 2001.

[http://www.incits.org/committees/l3.1 MPEG (L3.1 Task Group)] :* [http://www.incits.org/committees/l3.2 JPEG (L3.2 Task Group)] * [http://www.incits.org/committees/h3 Computer Graphics & Image Committee)] :* [http://www.incits.org/committees/dm32.2 Database (DM32.2 Task Group)] :* [http://www.incits.org/committees/dm32.8 Metadata (DM32.8 Technical Committee)] * Methods (B10 Technical Committee)] :* [http://www.incits.org/committees/b10.12 Integrated Circuit Cards with Contacts (B10.12 Task Group)] :* [http://www.incits.org/committees/b10.5 Contactless IC Cards (B10.5 Task Group)] :* [http://www.incits.org/committees/b10.8 Driver’s License/ID Cards (B10.8 Technical Committee)] :* [http://www.incits.org/committees/b10.11 Physical Characteristics and Test Methods (B10.11 Task Group)] * [http://www.incits.org/committees/iot10 Internet of Things (IoT) (IOT10 Technical Committee)] * [http://www.incits.org/committees/its39 IT Sustainability (ITS39 Technical Committee)] * Programming Languages (PL22 Technical Committee) - [http://www.incits.org/committees/pl22.3 Fortran (PL22.3 Task Group)], [http://www.incits.org/committees/pl22 COBOL (PL22.4 Task Group)], [http://www.incits.org/committees/pl22.11 C Language (PL22.11 Task Group)], [http://www.incits.org/committees/pl22.16 C++ Language (PL22.16 Task Group)] * [http://www.incits.org/committees/w1 Office Equipment (W1 Technical Committee)] * [http://www.incits.org/committees/t3 Open Systems (T3 Technical Committee)] * [http://www.incits.org/committees/smart-cities Smart Cities (SMART-CITIES Technical Committee)] * [http://www.incits.org/committees/t10 SCSI Storage Interfaces (T10 Technical Committee)]

Phillips Papers, 1959-1985] (Historical reference to BEMA)

{{Infobox industrial process | name = KENTORT II | image = | caption = | type = chemical | sector = [[Chemical industry]], [[oil industry]] | technologies = | feedstock = [[oil shale]] | product = [[shale oil]] | companies = | facility = | inventor = | year = | developer = Center for Applied Energy Research, [[University of Kentucky]] }} '''KENTORT II''' is an above-ground [[shale oil extraction]] process developed by the Center for Applied Energy Research of the [[University of Kentucky]]. It is a hot recycled solids [[fluidized bed]] retorting process developed since 1982 for processing the eastern [[United States]] [[Devonian]] [[oil shale]]s.<ref name=taulbee> {{Cite conference | last1 = Taulbee | first1 = D.N. | last2 = Carter | first2 = S.D. | title = Investigation of product coking induced by hot recycle solids in the KENTORT II fluidized bed retort | conference = Symposium on Chemistry, Structure and Reactivity of Coals, Tar Sands and Oil Shale | location = [[San Francisco]] |date=April 1992 | publisher = [[American Chemical Society]] | url = http://www.anl.gov/PCS/acsfuel/preprint%20archive/Files/37_2_SAN%20FRANCISCO_04-92_0800.pdf | format = PDF | pages = 800–809 | accessdate =2010-01-31}} </ref><ref name=taulbee2> {{Cite conference | last = Taulbee | first = D.N. | title = Measurement of the Adsorption and Cracking of Model Compounds Over Processed Oil Shale Particles | conference = | location = [[Denver]] |date=March 1993 | publisher = [[American Chemical Society]] | url = http://www.anl.gov/PCS/acsfuel/preprint%20archive/Files/38_1_DENVER_03-93_0324.pdf | format = PDF | pages = 324–329 | accessdate =2010-01-31}} </ref> The concept of this process was initiated in 1986 in the test unit.<ref name=vego> {{Cite conference | last1 = Vego | first1 = Asmund | last2 = Carter | first2 = Scott D. | last3 = Stehn | first3 = John L. | title = Investigation of product coking induced by hot recycle solids in the KENTORT II fluidized bed retort | conference = | location = [[Chicago]] |date=August 1993 | publisher = [[American Chemical Society]] | url = http://www.anl.gov/PCS/acsfuel/preprint%20archive/Files/38_3_CHICAGO_08-93_0972.pdf | format = PDF | pages = 972–978 | accessdate =2010-01-31}} </ref>
The KENTORT II retort consists of four fluidized bed vessels, configured in cascade. The raw oil shale is fed to the [[pyrolysis]] vessel the pyrolysis section, where it is fluidized by a mixture of steam and product [[oil shale gas]] from the gasification section below. Heat is transferred to the raw oil shale by a combination of fluidizing gas and recirculating hot [[spent shale]] from the gasification section. The pyrolysis takes place at {{convert|500|°C|°F|-1}} to {{convert|550|°C|°F|-1}}.<ref name=vego/><ref name=carter> {{Cite conference | last1 = Vego | first1 = Asmund | last2 = Carter | first2 = Scott D. | last3 = Stehn | first3 = John L. | last4 = Taulbee | first4 = D.N. | title = Effects of Scale-Up on Oil Shale and Gas Yields in a Solid-Recycle Fluidized Bed Oil Shale Retorting Process | conference = | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] |date=August 1994 | publisher = [[American Chemical Society]] | url = http://www.anl.gov/PCS/acsfuel/preprint%20archive/Files/39_4_WASHINGTON%20DC_08-94_1258.pdf | format = PDF | pages = 1253–1257 | accessdate =2010-01-31}} </ref>
The pyrolyzed oil shale moves by gravity downward to the gasification section. Gasification, which takes place at {{convert|750|°C|°F|-1}} to {{convert|850|°C|°F|-1}}, converts remained [[carbon]] in the spent shale ([[char]]) to product oil shale gas. Steam from the cooling zone is used for fluidizing the sent shale while heat transferred by hot solids (oil shale ash) from the combustion section. The spent shale moves to the combustion section where it is burnt to heat the process, while oil shale ash moves to the cooling section before its removal from the retort.<ref name=vego/>
==See also== * [[Galoter process]] * [[Alberta Taciuk Process]] * [[Petrosix|Petrosix process]] * [[Kiviter process]] * [[TOSCO II process]] * [[Fushun process]] * [[Paraho process]] * [[Lurgi-Ruhrgas process]] * [[Chevron STB process]] * [[LLNL HRS process]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[File:Bicycle diagram-en.svg|thumb|upright=2.6|Bicycle parts]]
For other '''cycling related terms''' (besides parts) see [[Glossary of cycling]].
'''List of [[bicycle]] parts''' by alphabetic order:
* '''[[Axle]]''': as in the generic definition, a rod that serves to attach a wheel to a bicycle and provides support for bearings on which the wheel rotates. Also sometimes used to describe suspension components, for example a swing arm pivot axle * '''[[Bar ends]]''': extensions at the end of straight handlebars to allow for multiple hand positions * '''[[Bicycle handlebar#Plugs|Bar plugs]]''' or '''end caps''': plugs for the ends of handlebars * '''[[Bicycle basket|Basket]]''': cargo carrier * '''[[Bearing (mechanical)|Bearing]]''': a device that facilitates rotation by reducing friction * '''[[Bicycle bell|Bell]]''': an audible device for warning pedestrians and other cyclists * '''[[Belt-driven bicycle|Belt-drive]]''': alternative to '''chain-drive''' * '''Bicycle brake cable''': see '''Cable''' * '''[[Bottle cage]]: '''a holder for a water bottle * '''[[Bottom bracket]]: '''The bearing system that the pedals (and cranks) rotate around. Contains a spindle to which the crankset is attached and the bearings themselves. There is a bearing surface on the spindle, and on each of the cups that thread into the frame. The bottom bracket may be overhaulable (an adjustable bottom bracket) or not overhaulable (a cartridge bottom bracket). The bottom bracket fits inside the bottom bracket shell, which is part of the bicycle frame * '''[[Bicycle brake|Brake]]''': devices used to stop or slow down a bicycle. '''Rim brakes''' and '''disc brakes''' are operated by brake levers, which are mounted on the handlebars. '''Band brake''' is an alternative to rim brakes but can only be installed at the rear wheel. '''Coaster brakes''' are operated by pedaling backward * '''[[Bicycle brake#Brake levers|Brake lever]]''': a lever for actuating a bicycle brake * '''[[Shifter (bicycle part)#Combined brake and shift levers|Brake shifter]]''' or colloquially, brifter (see also [[Shimano Total Integration]], [[Campagnolo ErgoPower]] and [[SRAM Double Tap]]): combined shifter and brake lever control * '''[[Braze-on]]''': a fitting protruding from a frame to provide attachment, typically for cable housings or tire pumps and similar accessories * '''[[Cable guide]]''': a fitting below the bottom bracket which guides a piece of bare inner [[bowden cable]] around a corner * '''[[Bowden cable|Cable]]''': a metal cable enclosed in part by a metal and plastic housing that is used to connect a control, such as a brake or shifting lever, to the device it activates * '''[[Cartridge bearing]]''': a type of bearing that is not user-serviceable, but must be replaced as a unit * '''[[Cogset#Cassettes|Cassette]]''': a group of stacked sprockets on the rear wheel of a bicycle with a rear derailleur * '''[[Coaster brake]]''' or backpedal brake * '''[[Bicycle chain|Chain]]''': a system of interlinking pins, plates and rollers that transmits power from the front sprocket(s) to the rear sprocket(s) * '''[[Gear case|Chainguard]]''': [[Gear case]] cover for the entire chain either totally encasing (sometimes containing [[Cycle oil|oil]]) or 'incomplete'. Either way, designed to keep clothing from fouling the chain. See also '''Skirtguard, [[Bashguard]].''' * '''[[Crankset#Chainring|Chainring]]''': (one of the) front gear(s), attached to a crank * '''[[Chainset]]''': see '''Crankset''' * '''[[Bicycle frame#Chain stays|Chainstay]]''': a pair of tubes on a bicycle frame that runs from the bottom bracket to the rear fork ends * '''[[Single-speed bicycle#Chain tensioning|Chain tensioner]]''': a device to maintain proper chain tension * '''[[Dropout (bicycle part)#Chaintugs|Chaintug]]''': a device to aid in setting the proper chain tension * '''Cluster''': a bicycle [[cogset]], either a freewheel, or cassette * '''[[Cogset]]''': the set of rear sprockets that attaches to the hub on the rear wheel * '''[[Race (bearing)|Cone]]''': holds bearings in place, pressed against the cup * '''[[Cotter (pin)|Cotter]]''': pin for attaching cottered [[Crankset#To the bottom bracket|cranks]] * '''[[Bicycle Torque Coupling|Coupler]]''': to connect tubing together * '''[[Crankset]]''' or '''chainset''': composed of cranks and at least one chainring * '''[[Cup and cone bearing|Cup]]''': receives ball bearings which roll along its inner surface; integrated on most conventional hubs or can be pressed into older bottom bracket shells. See also '''Cone''' * '''[[Cyclocomputer]]''': an electronic accessory that measures and displays instantaneous and cumulative speed and distance. Often provides other measurements such as heart rate * '''[[Derailleur hanger]]''': a piece on the rear [[Dropout (bicycle part)|dropout]] that the derailleur attaches to. * '''[[Derailleur]]''': an assembly of levers, usually cable actuated, that moves the chain between sprockets on a cassette or chainring assembly * '''[[Bicycle frame|Down tube]]''': tube on the bicycle frame that runs from the head tube to the bottom bracket * '''[[Dropout (bicycle part)|Dropout]]''': a bicycle rear fork end that allows the rear wheel to be removed without first derailing the chain. The term ''dropout'' is often incorrectly used to refer to any ''fork end'', but not all fork ends are dropouts * '''[[Dustcap]]''': any cap serving to keep dirt and contamination out of an assembly. Common over crank bolts, often plastic * '''[[Bicycle lighting#Dynamo systems|Dynamo]]''': bicycle lighting component, also known as '''generator''' * '''[[Dropout (bicycle part)#Eyelets|Eyelet]]''': :1) attachment point on frame, fork, or dropout for fenders, racks, etc. :2) a hole through which a [[spoke nipple]] passes through the rim so it may attach to a spoke * '''[[Electronic Gear-Shifting System]]''': not simply a type of shifter or a type of derailleur, a complete system with switches instead of levers, wires instead of Bowden cables, and motor-driven derailleurs that must all work together * '''[[Bicycle fairing|Fairing]]''': a full or partial covering for a bicycle to reduce aerodynamic drag or to protect the rider from the elements * '''[[Fender (vehicle)#Bicycles and motorcycles|Fender]]''' or '''mudguard''': curved pieces of metal or plastic above the tires which catch and redirect road spray thrown up by the tires, allowing the rider to remain relatively clean. May come in pairs * '''[[Ferrule]]''': a metal or plastic sleeve used to terminate the end of a cable housing * '''[[Bicycle fork|Fork]]''': a mechanical assembly that integrates a bicycle's frame to its front wheel and handlebars, allowing steering by virtue of its steerer tube * '''[[Fork end]]''': paired slots on a fork or frame at which the axle of the wheel is attached. See also '''Dropout''' * '''[[Bicycle frame|Frame]]''': the mechanical core of a bicycle, the frame provides points of attachment for the various components that make up the machine. The term is variously construed, and can refer to the base section, always including the bottom bracket, or to base frame, fork, and suspension components such as a shock absorber * '''[[Freehub]]''': a ratcheting assembly onto which a cog or cassette is mounted that allows the bicycle to coast without the pedals turning * '''[[Freewheel (bicycle part)|Freewheel]]''': a ratcheting assembly that incorporates one or more cogs and allows the bicycle to coast without the pedals turning * '''[[Gusset plate|Gusset]]''': plates added to the outsides of [[Bicycle frame|frame]] tubes to strengthen joints. These are more commonly seen on [[BMX bike|BMX]] and [[Mountain bike|mountain]] bikes * '''[[Derailleur hanger|Hanger]]''': part of frame or an attachment to the frame to which the derailleur is attached (see '''Derailleur hanger''') * '''[[Bicycle handlebar|Handlebar]]''': a lever attached, usually using an intermediary stem, to the steerer tube of the fork. Allows steering and provides a point of attachment for controls and accessories * '''Handlebar plug''': see '''Bar plugs''' * '''[[Bicycle handlebar#Tape|Handlebar tape]]''': a tape wound around dropped handlebars so as to provide padding and grip, usually cork or cloth, sometimes foam rubber * '''[[Head badge]]''': manufacturer's or brand logo affixed to the [[Bicycle frame#Head tube|head tube]] * '''[[Bicycle frame#Head tube|Head tube]]''': the tube of a bicycle frame that contains the headset * '''[[Headset (bicycle part)|Headset]]''': the bearings that form the interface between the frame and fork steerer tube * '''Hood''': the rubber brake lever covering on bikes with drop style handle bars * '''[[Bicycle wheel#Hub|Hub]]''': the core of a wheel; contains bearings and, in a traditional wheel, has drilled flanges for attachment of spokes * '''[[Hub dynamo]]''': a generator inside one of the hubs for powering lights or other accessories * '''[[Hub gear]]''': a gearbox mounted inside the hub, 3-speed is common, 5, 7 are available ("Sturmey-Archer") and Rohloff make a 14-speed hub. Cable operated by one or two cables * '''[[Bicycle lighting#Manually operated turn signals|Indicator]]''': a turn signal * '''[[Inner tube]]''': a bladder that contains air to inflate a tire. Has a Schrader, "Woods"/"Dunlop" or Presta valve for inflation and deflation * '''[[Jockey wheel]]''': one of two small sprockets of the rear derailleur that guides the chain * '''[[Kickstand]]''': a folding attachment used for assisting a bicycle to stand up on its own. Usually mounts to frame near bottom bracket, sometimes near rear dropouts * '''[[Dropout (bicycle part)#Lawyer lips|"Lawyer lips"]]''': also called a "'''lawyer tab'''", a retention device on the dropouts of the front fork to prevent inadvertent loss of the front wheel in the case it is not properly secured * '''[[Locknut]]''': a nut designed not to loosen due to vibration * '''[[Lockring]]''': a ring, usually metal, of varying design, that serves to retain a component in place * '''[[Lug (bicycle part)|Lug]]''': a metal connector used to align frame components where they join each other * '''[[Luggage carrier]]''': any accessory equipment designed to carry tools, gear or cargo * '''[[Master link]]''': a bicycle chain accessory that allows convenient removal and reconnection of an installed bicycle chain without the need for a chain tool * '''[[Spoke nipple|Nipple]]''': a specialized nut that most commonly attaches a spoke to a wheel rim. In some systems, it provides attachment to the hub * '''[[Pannier]]''': cloth zippered storage bags that mount to sides of luggage racks. Pronounced ''pan-ear'', or ''pan-yer'' (an old English word, which is derived from an old French word) * '''[[Bicycle pedal|Pedal]]''': mechanical interface between foot and crank arm. There are two general types; one secures the foot with a mechanical clamp or cage and the other has no connection to lock the foot to the pedal. * '''Peg''': short metal tube, about {{convert|6|in|cm}} long and {{convert|2|in|cm}} fastened to one or both ends of the wheel axles to either enable the rider perform certain [[Freestyle BMX#Tricks|tricks]] or provide a place for extra riders to stand or rest * '''[[Portage strap]]''': a strap (usually made of leather) attached to the inside of the bike frame, designed to make carrying the bike over one's shoulder easier * '''[[Quick release]]''': a skewer with a lever on one end that loosens when the lever is flipped. Used for releasing wheels and seat posts * '''[[Luggage carrier|Rack]]''': a rack that attaches behind the seat, usually with stays to the rear dropouts, that serves as a general carrier * '''[[retroreflector|Reflector]]''': reflects light to make bicycle evident when the illuminated by headlights of other vehicles. Usually required by law but held in disdain by many cyclists * '''Removable training wheels''': used for assisting balance. Comes in pair. Useful for first time bicyclists * '''[[Bicycle wheel#Rim|Rim]]''': that part of a wheel to which the tire is attached and often forms part of the braking mechanism * '''Rotor''': :1) the disc component of a disc [[Bicycle brake|brake]].<ref>[https://www.singletracks.com/mountain-bike/reviews/best_full.php?cat=Rotors https://www.singletracks.com] The Best Rotors.</ref> :2) another name for a [[detangler]] - a device that allows the handlebars and fork to revolve indefinitely without tangling the rear brake cable. * '''[[Bicycle brake systems#Mechanical|Safety levers]]''': extension levers, and interrupt brake levers. Used to apply brakes in order for the bicycle to slow down or suddenly stop * '''[[Bicycle saddle|Saddle]]''' or '''[[Bicycle seat|Seat]]''': what a bicyclist sits on * '''[[Bicycle saddle#Rails|Seat rails]]''': a metal framework over which saddle covering is stretched. The seat post attaches to the seat rails by means of a clamp * '''[[Seat lug]]''': a frame lug on the top of the seat tube serving as a point of attachment for a clamp to secure the seat post * '''[[Bicycle frame|Seat tube]]''': the roughly vertical tube in a bicycle frame running from the seat to the bottom bracket * '''[[Seat bag]]''': a small storage accessory hung from the back of a seat * '''[[Seatpost]]''': a post that the seat is mounted to. It slides into the frame's seat tube and is used to adjust ride height depending how far into the seat tube it is inserted * '''[[Bicycle frame|Seatstay]]''': frame components, small diameter tubes running from top of seat tube to rear dropouts * '''[[Shaft-driven bicycle|Shaft-drive]]''': alternate to '''chain-drive''' * '''[[Shifter (bicycle part)|Shifter]]''': gear shifting control * '''[[Shock absorber]]''': for bicycles with suspensions, a device that limits the rate at which suspension rebounds after absorbing an impact * '''Side view mirror''': aids in looking at the sides prior to moving slowly or turning to the left or to the right * '''[[Skirt guard]]''' or '''coatguard''': a device fitted over the rear wheel of a bicycle to prevent a long skirt, coat or other trailing clothes or luggage from catching in the wheel, or in the gap between the rim and the brakes * '''[[Bicycle pedal|Spindle]]''': an axle around which a pedal rotates; threaded at one end to screw into crank arms * '''[[Spoke]]''': connects wheel rim to hub. Usually wire with one end swaged to form a head and one threaded end. A typical wheel has 36 spokes * '''[[Sprocket]]''' or '''cog''': wheel with teeth that meshes with the chain; one of the wheels in the [[cogset]] or [[crankset]] * '''[[Bicycle fork|Steering tube]]''': a tube on top of a fork that is inserted through frame and serves as an axle by means of which bicycle can be steered * '''[[Stem (bike)|Stem]]''': a bracket used to attach handlebars to steerer tube of fork. Usually secured by pinch bolts * '''[[Bicycle tire|Tire]]''': as in common usage. Usually pneumatic. A [[Tubular tyre|tubular tire]] is glued to the wheel rim; most tires use tubes, but tubeless tires and rims are increasingly common * '''[[Bicycle pedal|Toe clips]]''': a metal or plastic cage attached to a pedal. Usually has an adjustment strap. Secures foot to pedal for increased control and more effective transfer of power from foot to drive chain * '''[[Bicycle frame|Top tube]]''': frame member leading from steerer tube to seat tube * '''[[Valve stem]]''' or simply '''valve''': port for adding or releasing air from the inner tube. Two types are commonly used: [[Presta valve|Presta]] and [[Schrader valve|Schrader]]. A third type, the [[Woods valve|Woods/Dunlop valve]], can still be found in Europe and Asia. * '''[[bicycle wheel|Wheel]]''': as in common usage. Traditionally and most commonly spoked * '''[[Wingnut (hardware)#Bicycles|Wingnut]]''': for attaching wheels before the development of the quick release skewer
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[27.5 Mountain bike]] *[[29er (bicycle)]] *[[Bicycle]] *[[Bicycle suspension]] *[[Bicycle tools]] *[[Bicycle wheel]] *[[BMX bike]] *[[Cycling]] *[[Downhill bike]] *[[Downhill mountain biking]] *[[Glossary of cycling]] *[[Groupset]] *[[Mountain biking]] *[[Mountain bike]] *[[Outline of cycling]] {{div col end}}

revision.text:
This '''list of missiles by country''' displays the names of [[missile]]s in order of the country where they originate (were developed), with the countries listed alphabetically and annotated with their continent (and defence alliance, if applicable). In cases where multiple nations have developed or produced a missile, it is listed under each significantly participating nation. Within the lists of each country, missiles are ordered by designation and/or calling name (the latter being especially relevant for Russian/Soviet missiles). In some cases multiple listings are used, in order to provide cross-references for easier navigation.
This is not a list of missiles in operational service by a particular country; nor a list of [[Rocket (weapon)|military rockets]]. [[Anti-tank missiles]] are [[List of anti-tank missiles|listed elsewhere]]
For an alphabetical list by missile name, see the [[list of missiles]]. {{TOC right}}
== Argentina == *[[Alacrán missile|''Alacrán'']] *[[AS-25K]] antiship, air-ground ASM *[[Condor missile|''Cóndor I'']] (with major contributions of German technology) *[[Condor missile|''Cóndor II'']] (in cooperation with several [[Middle East|Middle-East]]ern countries) *[[Condor missile|''Cóndor III'']] *[[Martin Pescador MP-1000]] antiship, air-ground ASM *[[Mathogo]] antitank, wire-guided
== Australia == *[[Ikara (missile)|Ikara]] *[[Malkara missile|Malkara]] (joint Australian/British) *[[Nulka]] active missile decoy designed to decoy antiship missiles away from their targets *ESSM *SM-3
== Brazil == *[[A-Darter (missile)|A-Darter]] Fifth generation short range infrared homing air-to-air missile (joint South Africa/Brazil) *[[FOG-MPM]] Fiber-Optical-Guided-Multipurpose-missile. *[[AVMT-300]] GPS and/or laser-guided long-range missile *[[Mectron MAA-1 Piranha|MAA-1A Piranha]] short-range infrared-homing air-to-air missile. *[[MAA-1B|MAA-1B Piranha]] air-to-air missile, also known as "Piranha II". *[[MSS-1.2|MSS-1.2 AC]] antitank [[guided missile]]. * MSA-3.1 AAé antiaircraft guided missile. * MAS-5.1 air-to-ground missile *[[MAR-1]] antiradiation missile (ARM). *[[MAN-1|MAN-1 (MANSUP)]] antiship missile
== Canada == *[[ERYX]] (joint French/Canadian) *[[Velvet Glove]]
== China == Missiles:<ref>http://www.ausairpower.net/APA-PLA-Cruise-Missiles.html</ref> *Red Arrow 73 *Red Arrow 8 *Red Arrow 9 *Red Arrow 10 GT6 * [[C-802]] (''Yingji'') antiship missile * KD-88 land-attack cruise missile * [[PL-5]] AAM * [[PL-7]] AAM * [[PL-9]] AAM * [[PL-10 (ASR)|PL-10]] AAM * [[PL-12]] AAM * CSS-2 * [[Dong Feng-3A]] MRBM * [[DF-4]] IRBM * [[DF-5]] ICBM * [[DF-15]] SRBM * [[DF-21]] MRBM * [[DF-31]] ICBM Range:8000 km * [[DF-31A]] ICBM Range:13000 km *[[DF-41]] ICBM * [[DH-10]] LACM * [[JL-1]] SLBM * [[JL-2]] SLBM Range:8000 km * [[SA-2 Guideline|Hongqi-1]] SAM * [[SA-2 Guideline|Hongqi-2]] SAM * [[SA-7 Grail|Hongnu-5]] SAM * [[HQ-7|Hongqi-7]] SAM * [[HQ-9|Hongqi-9]] SAM * [[SA-10 Grumble|Hongqi-10]] SAM * [[SA-10 Grumble|Hongqi-15]] SAM * [[SA-17 Grizzly|Hongqi-17]] SAM * [[SA-12 Gladiator/Giant|Hongqi-18]] SAM * [[Hongqi-61]] SAM * [[Kaishan-1]] SAM * [[Lieying-60]] SAM * [[PenLung-9]] SAM * [[Anza (missile)|Qianwei-1]] SAM * Qianwei-2 SAM * [[Silkworm missile]] short-range antiship subsonic cruise missile
== European joint-venture == * [[AIM-132 ASRAAM]] * [[MBDA Aster]] * [[MBDA Meteor]] * [[IRIS-T]] *[[Martel (missile)|Martel]] – Anglo-French: Models AJ 168 and AS.37 *[[MIM-115 Roland]] *[[KEPD 350|Taurus KEPD 150/350]]
== France == * [[AASM]] * [[Aerospatiale AS-12]] * [[MBDA Apache|Apache]] * [[AS-30L|AS.30]] * [[Air-Sol Moyenne Portée|ASMP]] * [[Crotale missile|Crotale]] surface-to-air missile * [[Entac|ENTAC]] * [[ERYX]] (France-Canada) * [[Masurca]] (Naval SAM)
== Germany == [[File:IRIS-T air-to-air-missile.jpg|thumb|right|A modern [[German Air Force]] [[IRIS-T]] infrared homing air-to-air missile]] [[File:BGT IDAS.jpg|thumb|right|Model of [[IDAS (missile)|IDAS]] of the [[German Navy]].]] *[[AS.34 Kormoran|AS.34 Kormoran 1/2]] *[[MIM-115 Roland]] (replaced by [[LFK NG]]) *[[ESSM]] *[[Spike (missile)|EuroSpike]] (Israel/Germany) *[[KEPD 350|Taurus KEPD 350]] *[[AGM Armiger]] *[[IRIS-T]] *[[IRIS-T|IRIS-T SL]] *[[IDAS (missile)]] *[[PARS 3 LR]] *[[RBS-15]] (Sweden/Germany) *[[GMLRS]] *[[MEADS]] *[[RIM-116 RAM]] *[[LFK NG]] *[[MBDA Meteor]] (Multinational) *[[Euromissile HOT]] (Franco German) antitank missile *[[MILAN]]

== India == [[File:Brahmos imds.jpg|thumb| [[BrahMos]] shown at IMDS 2007.|300x300px]] [[File:Pinaka.JPG|300px| thumb | [[Pinaka multi barrel rocket launcher|Pinaka MBRL]] truck]]

== Iran == {{main|Iranian missile tests}} {{asof|2009}}, Iran has an active interest in developing, acquiring, and deploying a broad range of ballistic missiles, as well as developing a space launch capability. In mid-July 2008, Iran launched a number of ballistic missiles during military exercises, reportedly including the medium-range Shahab-3. Iran announced other missile and space launch tests in August and November 2008. In February 2009, Iran announced it launched a satellite into orbit and "officially achieved a presence in space."<ref name="CRS1">{{CRS|article = Iran's Ballistic Missile Programs: An Overview|url = https://fas.org/sgp/crs/nuke/RS22758.pdf}}</ref> {{Iran missiles|state=expanded}}

Sequence Numbers:
Air Force: Consecutive numerical sequence for each missile mission type.
Army: Single numerical sequence until 1948 when the sequence numbers were restarted.
Navy: Initially even numbers transitioning to sequential.

<sup>2</sup>The X-11 and X-12 designations were assigned to one and three engine test missiles that would have been used to develop a five-engine version of the Atlas missile.<ref name="Parsch" />
'''United States Air Force Designation System, 1955–1963'''<ref name="Parsch" />
{| class="wikitable" |- style="background:silver;" || Status Prefix|| style="background:silver;"| Basic Mission || style="background:silver;"| Sequence Number || style="background:silver;"| Modification Series |- ||H – Hardened ||GAM – Guided Air-Launched Missile |||| |- ||R – Reconnaissance ||GAR – Guided Air-Launched Rocket |||| |- ||S – Space ||IM – Intercept Missile |||| |- ||T – Training ||RM – Research Missile |||| |- ||U – Training ||SM – Strategic Missile |||| |- ||X – Experimental ||TM – Tactical Missile |||| |- ||Y – Service Test |||||| |}
For all basic missions except GAR (which started at 1) the sequence number started after 67 which was the last bomber designation used for guided missiles.<ref name="Parsch" />
Sample Air Force 1955–1963 designation: "XSM-73"

page.title: Minister of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change (Malaysia)

revision.comment: Euricko moved page [[Minister of Energy, Technology, Science, Climate Change and Environment (Malaysia)]] to [[Minister of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change (Malaysia)]]: New official name
revision.text:
{{Infobox official post | post = Minister of Energy, Technology, Science, Climate Change and Environment | body = | native_name = | flag = | flagsize = | flagcaption = | insignia = Coat_of_arms_of_Malaysia.svg | insigniasize = | insigniacaption = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | incumbent = [[Yeo Bee Yin]] | incumbentsince = {{startdate|2018|7|2|df=y}} | type = | status = | department = [[Ministry of Energy, Technology, Science, Climate Change and Environment (Malaysia)|Ministry of Energy, Technology, Science, Climate Change and Environment]] | style = Yang Berhormat Menteri
(The Honourable Minister) | member_of = [[Cabinet of Malaysia]] | reports_to = [[Parliament of Malaysia]] | residence = | seat = [[Putrajaya]] | nominator = | appointer = [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]] on the recommendation of the [[Prime Minister of Malaysia]] | appointer_qualified = | termlength = | termlength_qualified = | constituting_instrument = | precursor = | formation = 1970 | first = [[Ong Kee Hui]]
as Minister of Technology, Research and Local Government | last = | abolished = | succession = | abbreviation = | unofficial_names = | deputy = [[Isnaraissah Munirah Majilis]] | salary = | website = {{URL|http://www.kettha.gov.my/}} }} The current Malaysian '''Minister of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change (MESTECC)''' is [[Yeo Bee Yin]], since 2 July 2018.{{cite news|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2018/07/02/yeo-energy-green-technology-science-climate-change-and-environment-minister|title=Yeo is Energy, Green Technology, Science, Climate Change and Environment Minister|author=Elly Fazaniza|publisher=''[[The Sun, Malaysia|The Sun Daily]]''|date=2 July 2018|accessdate=4 July 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.hmetro.com.my/mutakhir/2018/07/353895/sukarelawan-kini-bergelar-menteri|title=Sukarelawan kini bergelar Menteri|author=|publisher=''[[Harian Metro]]''|date=2 July 2018|accessdate=4 July 2018}} The minister is supported by Deputy Minister of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change. The minister administers the portfolio through the [[Ministry of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change (Malaysia)|Ministry of Energy, Science, Technology, Environment and Climate Change]]. == List of ministers of energy == The following individuals have been appointed as Minister of Energy, or any of its precedent titles: '''Political Party:''' {{legend2|{{Alliance Party (Malaysia)/meta/color}}|[[Alliance Party (Malaysia)|Alliance]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|{{Barisan Nasional/meta/color}}|[[Barisan Nasional|BN]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|{{Pakatan Harapan/meta/color}}|[[Pakatan Harapan|PH]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! colspan=2|Portrait ! {{Infobox official post |post = Minister of Science and Sport |body = Canada |flag = Government of Canada signature.svg |flagsize = 200px |flagcaption = |insignia = |insigniasize = |insigniacaption = |image = Kirsty Duncan St. John's Rally.jpg |incumbent = [[Kirsty Duncan]] |incumbentsince = 4 November 2015 |department = [[Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada]] |style = [[The Honourable]] |member_of = {{hlist |[[Cabinet of Canada|Cabinet]] ||[[Privy Council of Canada|Privy Council]]}} |reports_to = |residence = |seat = |appointer = [[Governor General of Canada]] |appointer_qualified = |termlength = [[At Her Majesty's pleasure]] |termlength_qualified = |formation = February 23, 1990 |inaugural = [[Benoît Bouchard]] |salary = $255,300 (2017){{cite web|url=https://lop.parl.ca/ParlInfo/Lists/Salaries.aspx?Menu=HOC-Politic&Section=03d93c58-f843-49b3-9653-84275c23f3fb|title=Indemnities, Salaries and Allowances|publisher=Parliament of Canada}} (CAD) |website = [http://www.ic.gc.ca www.ic.gc.ca] }} The '''Minister of Science and Sport''', formerly the '''Minister of Science''', is an office in the [[Cabinet of Canada]] that originally existing from 1990 to 1995 and was brought back in 2008. == History == Prior to 1990, the responsibilities of the Industry, Science and Technology portfolio were divided between the now-defunct post of [[Minister of Regional Industrial Expansion (Canada)|Minister of Regional Industrial Expansion]] and a Minister of State for Science and Technology. In 1995, the portfolio was merged with that of the [[Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs (Canada)|Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs]] to create the post of [[Minister of Industry (Canada)|Minister of Industry]]. In the appointments to the [[Cabinet of Canada]] of October 30, 2008 under [[Stephen Harper]], the portfolio was reintroduced as a [[Minister of State (Canada)|Minister of State]] and given to [[Gary Goodyear]]. === Trudeau government === In 2015, [[Kirsty Duncan]] was appointed a Minister of State styled as "Minister of Science" to assist the [[Minister of Industry]] (the senior portfolio was also renamed the [[Minister of Innovation, Science and Economic Development]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.pco-bcp.gc.ca/oic-ddc.asp?lang=eng&txtToDate=&txtPrecis=&Page=secretariats&txtOICID=&txtAct=&txtBillNo=&txtFromDate=2015-11-04&txtDepartment=&txtChapterNo=&txtChapterYear=&rdoComingIntoForce=&DoSearch=Search+/+List&pg=8&viewattach=31588&blnDisplayFlg=1 |title=Order in Council PC Number: 2015-1225 |date=2015-11-04 |website=Privy Council Office |publisher=Government of Canada |access-date=2015-11-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151109121851/http://www.pco-bcp.gc.ca/oic-ddc.asp?lang=eng&txtToDate=&txtPrecis=&Page=secretariats&txtOICID=&txtAct=&txtBillNo=&txtFromDate=2015-11-04&txtDepartment=&txtChapterNo=&txtChapterYear=&rdoComingIntoForce=&DoSearch=Search%20%2F%20List&pg=8&viewattach=31588&blnDisplayFlg=1 |archive-date=2015-11-09 |dead-url=no |df= }} Duncan's portfolio was expected to oversee [[basic research]], while [[Navdeep Bains]] would oversee [[applied science]].{{Cite web|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/news/politics/why-canadian-science-now-has-two-ministers|title=Why Canada now has two science ministers|website=Ottawa Citizen|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-21}} In July 2018, the office's portfolio was expanded, being renamed to "Minister of Science and Sport".{{cite news |title=Complete list of Justin Trudeau's updated cabinet |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/cabinet-shuffle-list-1.4751452 |accessdate=21 July 2018 |work=CBC News |date=July 18, 2018}} The Official Opposition Shadow Minister for Science is [[Matt Jeneroux]] Member of Parliament for Edmonton Riverbend. ==Ministers== '''Key:''' {{legend|{{Canadian party colour|CA|Liberal}}|[[Liberal Party of Canada]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = [[Kingdom of Thailand]]
Ministry of Energy | type = Ministry |abbreviation = MOE |nativename = |nativename_a = กระทรวงพลังงาน |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = {{Start date and age|3 October 2002}} |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Thailand]] |headquarters = 555/2 Energy Complex Building B, Vibhavadi-Rangsit Rd, [[Chatuchak District|Chatuchak]], [[Bangkok]] 10900 |coordinates = |employees = |budget = 2,010,448,900 baht (2011)[http://www.ratchakitcha.soc.go.th/DATA/PDF/2553/A/060/1.PDF พระราชบัญญัติงบประมาณรายจ่ายประจำปีงบประมาณ พ.ศ. 2554] |minister1_name = Siri Jirapongphan |minister1_pfo = ''Minister of Energy'' |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = [http://www.energy.go.th/ www.energy.go.th] |footnotes = }} The '''Ministry of Energy of the Kingdom of Thailand''' ({{lang-th|กระทรวงพลังงาน}}; RTGS: Krasuang Phalang Ngan) is a cabinet ministry in the [[Government of Thailand]]. == History == Disparate energy departments were consolidated by the government with the establishment of the National Energy Policy Committee in 1992 (B.E.2535) under the National Energy Policy Council Act (1992). It is responsible for managing the energy sector in Thailand, including granting energy operating licenses and issuing energy pricing regulations. [[Thaksin Shinawatra]], then prime minister in 2002, established the Bureau of Energy on 2 November 2001, B.E.2544, which was later upgraded to the Ministry of Energy in 2002 pursuant to the Restructuring of Government Organization Act (2002).http://www.fao.org/docrep/012/i1285e/i1285e08.pdfhttp://www.energy.go.th/?q=en/profile == Organization== === Administration === * Office of the Minister * Office of the Permanent Secretary === Dependent departments === * Department of Mineral Fuels * Department of Energy Business * Department of Alternative Energy Development and Efficiency (DEDE) * Energy Policy and Planning Office === State enterprises === * [[Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand]] (EGAT) * [[PTT Public Company Limited]] * Bangchak Petroleum Public Company Limited ==Thailand Power Development Plan 2015-2036 (PDP2025)== Thailand's Power Development Plan (PDP).{{cite book|title=Thailand Power Development Plan 2015-2036 (PDP2015)|date=2015-06-30|publisher=Ministry of Energy (MOE), Energy Policy and Planning Office (EPPO)|location=Bangkok|url=http://www.egat.co.th/en/images/about-egat/PDP2015_Eng.pdf|accessdate=30 September 2016}} is the nation's roadmap for electric power generation, distribution, and consumption. The plan, prepared by the Ministry of Energy (MOE) and EGAT, is issued iteratively. The previous edition, PDP2010 Revision 3, covered the years 2012-2030. Along with the PDP, the MOE produces several subsidiary plans that roll up into the PDP:{{RP|1-1}} * Energy Efficiency Development Plan (EEDP) * Alternative Energy Development Plan (AEDP) * Natural Gas Supply Plan * Petroleum Management Plan PDP2015 begins with the assumptions that:{{RP|2-3}} * Thailand's average [[GDP]] growth over the period 2014-2036 will be 3.94 percent annually * Thailand's population growth over the same period will average 0.03 percent annually * Energy savings over the period as forecasted in the EEDP will total 89,672 GWh * Renewables, including domestic hydro, will supply 19,634.4 MW of power over the period * Thailand's new power demands will grow 2.67 percent annually, 2014-2036 * In 2036 Thailand's peak electricity demand will be 49,655 MW and that total electricity demand will be 326,119 GWh PDP2015 projects the following changes in Thailand electrical power generation fuel mix over the period 2014-2036:{{RP|2-1}} * Imported hydro-power: Rising from 7 percent in 2014 to 15-20 percent in 2036 * Coal/lignite: Flat to rising from 20 percent to 20-25 percent * Renewables, including domestic hydro: Rising from 8 percent to 15-20 percent * Natural gas: Declining from 64 percent to 30-40 percent * Nuclear: Rising from 0 percent to 0-5 percent * Diesel/fuel oil: Declining from 1 percent to zero PDP2015 projects that Thailand's CO2 emissions from power generation will rise from 86,998,000 tons in 2015 to 104,075,000 tons in 2036.{{RP|7-1}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.energy.go.th/?q=th/ Ministry of Energy] (Thai) *[http://energy.go.th/2015/en/ Ministry of Energy] (English) {{ThaiCabinetDept}} [[Category:Energy ministries|Thailand, Ministry of Energy]] [[Category:Government ministries of Thailand|Energy]] [[Category:Ministries established in 2002|Thailand, Energy]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Thailand]]

{{Infobox company | name = Movandi | logo = | type = Private | industry = [[Telecommunications]]
[[Semiconductors]]
[[5G ]]
[[Mobil]]e
[[Wireless]] | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founded = 2016 | founder = Maryam Rofougaran,
Reza Rofougaran | defunct = | hq_location_city = [[Newport Beach]], [[California]] | hq_location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | area_served = | key_people = | products = BeamX 28
BeamX 39 | revenue = | owner = | num_employees = 40 | num_employees_year = | parent = | website = {{URL|movandi.com/}} }} '''Movandi''' is an American venture backed [[startup company]], founded by Maryam Reza and Rofougaran based in [[Newport Beach, California]]. The company is focused on solving the technical challenges of [[5G]] [[high frequency]] and [[Millimeter-wave|millimeter wave]] networks by providing scalable, integrated [[Radio frequency|RF]], antenna technology and systems.{{Cite news|url=http://www.eenewseurope.com/news/sibling-startup-offers-rf-5g-0|title=Sibling startup offers RF for 5G|date=2017-09-26|work=eeNews Europe|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.microwavejournal.com/articles/29000-movandi-brings-innovative-rf-front-end-technology-to-emerging-mmwave-5g-networks|title=Movandi Brings Innovative RF Front-End Technology to Emerging mmWave 5G Networks|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}} The business provides technology to [[Telephone company|carriers]], [[handset]] providers, wired and wireless companies, and is embedded in [[Semiconductor device|semiconductor chips]] and systems. == History == The company was founded in 2016, by two siblings Maryam Rofougaran and Reza Rofougaran. Movandi’s BeamX solutions launched in 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1332244|title=5G Startup Aims to Beat Intel, Q’comm|last=|first=|date=|website=EE Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.electronicproducts.com/Education/Career/The_top_5_technology_innovators.aspx|title=The top 5 technology innovators|website=Electronic Products|access-date=2018-11-23}} == Overview == Movandi builds [[mmWave]] antenna arrays that are more compact, more power-efficient over a wider power range, more spectrally efficient, and cheaper to produce.{{Cite web|url=https://www.edn.com/electronics-blogs/5g-waves/4458814/Movandi-optimizes-mmWave-5G-front-ends|title=Movandi optimizes mmWave 5G front ends|last=|first=|date=|website=EDN Network|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.everythingrf.com/News/details/5595-Movandi-Works-with-Keysight-to-Advance-Testing-for-mmWave-5G-Technology|title=Movandi Works with Keysight to Advance Testing for mmWave 5G Technology|last=|first=|date=|website=everything RF|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Movandi has 40 patents designed as a complete system combining the entire front-end and antenna system rather than a mix and match of individual components. They develop [[RF CMOS or CMOS RF|RF CMOS]] across cellular, [[microwave]] backhaul, [[Wi-Fi|wi-fi]], [[Bluetooth]], [[Global Positioning System|GPS]]/[[GNSS]], [[Near-field communication|NFC]], [[Femtocell|Femto cell]], and other standards including the integration of multiple standards into a single chip.{{Cite news|url=https://www.developingtelecoms.com/tech/wireless-networks/7617-movandi-unveils-5g-rf-front-end-millimeter-wave-solutions.html|title=Movandi Unveils 5G RF Front-End Millimeter Wave Solutions|last=Channing|first=Ian|date=2018-02-23|work=Developing Telecoms|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mwrf.com/systems/startup-makes-5g-its-priority|title=Startup Makes 5G its Priority|date=2018-03-14|work=Microwaves & Radio Frequency|access-date=2018-11-23}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.electronicsweekly.com/news/keysight-millimetre-wave-start-address-5g-test-challenges-2018-02/|title=Keysight and millimetre-wave start-up address 5G test challenges|date=2018-02-09|work=Electronics Weekly|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.microwavejournal.com/articles/29759-movandi-keysight-collaborate-to-advance-mmwave-technology-test-capabilities|title=Movandi, Keysight Collaborate to Advance mmWave Technology, Test Capabilities|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.eettaiwan.com/news/article/20180403NT31-Are-Your-5-Fingers-Blocking-your-5G|title=5G商用熱身賽開跑|last=|first=|date=|website=eettaiwan|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==== Investors ==== Cota Capital - [[Sierra Ventures]] - Wistron NeWeb Corporation{{Cite news|url=https://movandi.com/about/|title=About|work=Movandi|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en-US}} == Awards == * [[IEEE Circuits and Systems Society|IEEE Circuts & Systems Society]] 2018 Awards - Industrial Pioneer Award, June 2018{{Cite web|url=http://ieee-cas.org/ieee-circuits-and-systems-society-2018-awards|title=IEEE Circuits and Systems Society 2018 Awards {{!}} IEEE CAS|website=ieee-cas.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-23}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ee.ucla.edu/16423-2/|title=Ahmadreza (Reza) Rofougaran to receive the 2018 IEEE Circuits and Systems Industrial Pioneer Award {{!}} EE|website=www.ee.ucla.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-23}} * [[Light Reading|Light Reading’s]] 2018 Leading Lights Award - Female-Led Startup to Watch, May 2018{{Cite news|url=https://www.lightreading.com/business-employment/women-in-comms/announcingwics-2018-leading-lights-winners/a/d-id/743081|title=Announcing...WiC's 2018 Leading Lights Winners {{!}} Light Reading|work=Light Reading|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en}} * Light Reading’s 2018 Leading Lights Award - Most Innovative 5G Technology, May 2018{{Cite news|url=https://www.lightreading.com/automation/leading-lights-2018-the-winners/d/d-id/743054?page_number=2|title=Leading Lights 2018: The Winners {{!}} Light Reading|work=Light Reading|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en}} * Connected World - IoT Women of M2M (WoM2M) ,May 2018{{Cite news|url=https://connectedworld.com/women-lead-in-a-new-age-of-innovation/#Maryam%20Rofougaran|title=Women Lead in a New Age of Innovation|work=Connected World|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en}} * [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] Samueli 2018 Award - UCLA 2018 Alumnus of the Year, March 2018{{Cite web|url=https://samueli.ucla.edu/ucla-samueli-honors-alumni-faculty-and-students-at-2018-awards-dinner|title=UCLA Samueli honors alumni, faculty, and students at 2018 awards dinner {{!}} UCLA Samueli School Of Engineering|website=samueli.ucla.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-23}} * Electronic Products - Top 5 Technology Innovators, December 2017{{Cite web|url=https://www.electronicproducts.com/Education/Career/The_top_5_technology_innovators.aspx|title=The top 5 technology innovators|website=Electronic Products|access-date=2018-11-23}} * [[Edison Awards]] - Women Behind Innovation, April 2018{{Cite news|url=http://www.edisonawards.com/news/women-behind-innovation-maryam-rofougaran/|title=Women Behind Innovation: Maryam Rofougaran - Edison Awards News|date=2018-04-06|work=Edison Awards News|access-date=2018-11-23|language=en-US}} * [[EE Times]] - Women in Tech: Profile in Persistence, September 2017{{Cite web|url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1332611&page_number=20|title=Women in Tech: 25 Profiles in Persistence|last=|first=|date=|website=EE TImes|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://movandi.com/ Official Website] [[Category:Telecommunications companies of the United States‏‎]] [[Category:Telecommunications companies]] [[Category:Semiconductor companies‏‎]] [[Category:Technology companies]] [[Category:Wi-Fi]]
